request_pathways.name: Authorization to Use and Disclose Protected Health Information

forms.document_type: Third-party release of medical records authorization
Third-party release of medical records authorization

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic HIPAA authorization form from the GI Alliance website, prints and handwrites it, then must contact the organization to learn where to submit it.

red_flags: No submission instructions on any form — patient has no way to know where to send completed authorization
Blank provider identity and revocation address create functional barriers for patients
Affiliate forms (form-2, form-3) collect last 4 digits of SSN, which is unnecessary and may deter patients
Using §164.508 authorization framework for patient access instead of §164.524 Right of Access
bright_spots: Sensitive information categories require separate initials (HIV/AIDS, mental health, substance use, genetic info)
Explicit non-conditioning statement clearly tells patients treatment won't depend on signing
Concise single-page format covers all essential authorization elements without excessive density

findability.rationale: Level 3: requires moderate effort — the form is publicly hosted and surfaced by web search, but the patient forms page is organized by local brand/location with no dedicated 'Request Your Records' link, requiring non-obvious navigation.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: primarily a paper workflow — the form is text-based (not a scan) but has zero fillable fields, no electronic signature, and no submission pathway specified; patient must print, handwrite, and determine submission method independently.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: adequate but with notable problems — the single-page format is concise and logically ordered, but uses legalistic language ('d/b/a', 'HIPAA Affiliated Covered Entity'), lacks section headers, has no instructional text, and leaves critical fields (provider name, revocation address) blank.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: a patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the 'Patient's Request' checkbox makes the generic authorization usable for self-access, but the form doesn't reference patient rights, offer delivery format choices, or distinguish self-access from third-party release.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: some requirements or language that may go beyond what the law requires — the form includes all required HIPAA authorization elements (expiration, revocation, non-conditioning) but conflates §164.508 authorization with §164.524 patient access, has no fee disclosure, and blank address fields undermine revocation rights.

overall.summary: GI Alliance provides a minimally functional but patient-unfriendly records request pathway, funneling all requests through a generic non-fillable authorization form with no submission instructions and no acknowledgment of patient self-access as a distinct right.
